segments.text: Well, I had started graduate work at Princeton in 1941, and the major professor was Professor Wigner, W-I-G-N-R. And after Pearl Harbor, of course, there was a lot of additional work in this field, and they decided to concentrate the
theoretical and experimental work on nuclear piles at the University of Chicago.
So, physics professors from several universities around the country went there.
Two of them from Princeton went, Professor Wheeler and Professor Wigner that I was working with.
And he took me along with him at that time.
Before you went, did you know what type of research was going on there and what its ultimate goal was at that time?
Well, it depends what you mean by the ultimate goal.
We had worked on this some back at Princeton and we thought that it was the primary purpose was to make nuclear power plants and also to
as a byproduct, make some of the fissionable materials, which might have some other applications, which was rather, well, it wasn't dwelt upon what it might be.
And it wasn't actually until, oh, I suppose 1944 or 45, early 45, that many of us realized that it had anything to do with the bomb.
Is that right?
Yeah.
So you thought you were still...
working primarily toward power rather than a weapons use.
Right.
It's amazing, but that's true.
Okay.
What exactly was your role there at the University of Chicago as related to the first reactor?
Well, I was the assistant to Professor Bigner, and we did a lot of the early calculations about how reactors work and what happens to the
neutrons after they come out of the atom that undergoes fission, how they are slowed down by the carbon, all of these piles at that time were made of carbon with cylinders of uranium in them.
Okay.
We set the scene prior to 2nd of December 1942 and include the problems of getting enough fissionable material
whether to use graphite or heavy water to slow down the neutrons or any other major problems that were going on at the time?
Well, there were many.
Well, just about anything you mentioned there.
In the first place, they decided to try to do it with natural uranium.
because there just wasn't enough enriched uranium at that time.
So that meant that you had to have the uranium in cylinders, and you had to have something around the uranium that slowed down the neutrons to thermal energy sufficiently.
And as you say, probably the two main candidates were carbon and heavy water.
I think, again, it was just a question that there wasn't
that much heavy water available at that time.
There were very small quantities, but you need a lot for a reactor.
Yeah, I read in The New World by Hewlett and Anderson that they only had a small quantity in Canada, in a plant in Canada, even though it was a much preferred material over carbon.
But they just couldn't manufacture enough at the time of the experiment.
And the carbon reactor was very easy to build.
Its only disadvantage was it had to be considerably larger than the heavy water one.
Why is that, that it has to be larger?
Well, just because it doesn't slow down the neutrons as efficiently, and it has somewhat higher absorption of the neutrons than the carbon.
The smaller a reactor is, of course, the more loss of neutrons you have,
out of the sides relative to the number you're making.
So if you have a more inefficient moderator, you've got to have a larger reactor.
OK.
The material then, did you all end up using uranium-235, or did you use natural uranium-238?
No, it was just natural uranium.
So it involved a lot of uranium then.
A lot of uranium and a lot of carbon.
And they were doing this under very strict security there.
It was all done under the old stadium at the University of Chicago, which when I first went there had been squash courts, a game they like to play in the Northeast, but not in Texas, I guess.
Like racquetball down here.
It's very similar, I think.
The ball doesn't bounce in squash.
I've played it several times.
The first time I got the ball, I was going to play, and I dropped the ball, and it just didn't bounce.
Yeah.
Well, I don't know if I can play this.
But you can really get that ball going fast.
I played it some before they abolished the squash courts to make the reactor.
It was the only large place they could find to do it.
So they did this under the old football stands at the university.
They...
only had a small number of people cleared with a security clearance to do this work.
And you didn't have any manual laborers at all, because you didn't have anybody of that sort with clearance.
So all the graduate students, including myself, were drafted to do things like carry the blocks of carbon onto the pile and so on.
And this was heavy, dirty work.
Yeah, I understand the carbon.
real messy, and it was real slick.
Right.
I ruined a pair of shoes doing that.
Can you tell me about the actual reaction when it actually happened to include the guys in the suicide squad with the buckets of cadmium solution?
I don't know as I remember exactly who that was.
I haven't thought of this for a long time.
It's in some of the standard accounts, of course.
Yes.
But what was their purpose, the Suicide Squad?
Well, just to be sure the thing didn't blow up, it was completely unchartered territory.
And although everybody thought they'd taken account of everything in the calculations that could be taken account of, how could you really be sure?
And so as an additional safety precaution, they had these people there with cadmium in solution, which is a very strong absorber of neutrons.
And if anything went wrong, they were to dump it on the pile, which supposedly would have absorbed the excess neutrons and helped stop whatever was happening that shouldn't.
But it didn't go that way.
Everything worked just beautifully.
They very slowly withdrew the control rods, which of course absorb neutrons too, and as they pull them out, why, the number of neutrons in the pile goes up.
And it just went up on a beautiful exponential curve.
Right with the calculations in it?
Yeah, yeah.
Okay, so the reaction, how long did it take from the time you started removing the rods until they decided that the factor was one, that it was a self-sustaining reaction?
Oh, dear.
If I had to guess after this long time, I'd say it was five or ten minutes, probably.
Is that right?
Yeah.
Okay.
A. H. Compton, in his book, Atomic Quest,
watches three people's faces during the reaction.
Enrico Fermi, who was cool, in control, and showed no sign of elation.
Balney Wilson, who looked troubled because of the destruction that reaction implied.
And Crawford Greenwald, later the president of DuPont, the look of a man who had seen a miracle, a source of endless power.
Did any of these fit your reaction?
Do you remember what came to your mind when y'all actually had a self-sustaining reaction?
Well, I suspect he's reading a lot into the faces of those three people in terms of what he knows about the people.
Well, I suspect a little bit of all those things.
It certainly was a very humbling moment.
One certainly did a good bit of thinking about where all this was taking one.
But as I say, at that point, at least those of us who were graduate students didn't know anything about the tremendous destructive potential that was possible.
What type of work did you do after the reaction?
After that famous day?
Well, I just continued doing theoretical work about it.
There were just many, many different things that needed to be worked out to understand it better.
And then they were also, of course, looking at better ways to make nuclear reactors with other substances and other configurations.
Did you give any consideration in going to Los Alamos?
No, it was never suggested that this particular group would go.
I see.
So they already had a core of people there that they were going to work with?
Yeah, now some of the very top physicists that were at Chicago eventually ended up at Los Alamos.
And I think they may have taken a few of their own graduate students with them.
But no one that was in the group I was in went there.
In fact, we knew very little about it because, again, they tried to keep all these
places separate for secret series.
Well, did that inhibit you then in your research, since obviously at the University of California you had one group of people?
What, at Princeton and Cornell they had a group?
The University of Chicago?
I think after, say, the end of 1942, there weren't
these groups at all these universities.
There was the group at the University of Chicago that did piles.
There was the group at Oak Ridge that did the diffusion of the isotopes.
There was a group at Los Alamos that did the weapons.
And that was about it, wasn't it?
Yeah, those were the main ones as far as from what I've read in directing
to actually get the weapon.
Everything I've read, that's the whole, it seemed like that was, you could say that's the whole ball of wax.
They were all going toward a weapon, which now I'm sort of surprised when you told me that you all thought the major thrust of your research was for power.
Yeah.
Yeah, I don't think it was at least until the end of the 40s.
that maybe you have to suspect there might be a lot more to it.
Okay, with the research going on in the Superbomb, the FAST reactor project, the large Van de Graaff accelerator, why did so many scientists leave the lab at Los Alamos after 1945?
Was it because they felt their job was over, or the uncertainty of the lab's future?
Do you know about some of the feelings of the people who left there?

Well, I suppose there may have been many different reasons, but I suspect that a lot of them were just university scientists that wanted to get back to their own research labs and work on their own projects again after doing this big general project.
When I first looked at the members of the Atomic Energy Commission, it was Mr. Pike from the Security Exchange Commission,
Lilienthal from the Tennessee Valley Authority, Wayne Rack, a newspaper editor, Strauss, who was a partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Company, and the only scientist was Robert Baish from Cornell.
Why was there such a lack of scientists on the Atomic Energy Commission when it first formed?
I haven't any idea.
You think it was just a political commission then?
No idea on that.
I really don't know that.
What role did the Atomic Energy Commission play in encouraging nuclear research?
You mean during the war or after?
After the war, yes.
Well, of course, they started funding research at many universities, so in that sense they certainly encouraged university research.
And they did continue to make Los Alamos quite an attractive place for a scientist to be.
In what respect did they do that?
Just the number of projects they had going on there?
Yeah, they had a lot of projects, good financing, and a lot of famous people around which you could contact and discuss ideas with and so on.
I spent one summer there a few years after the war.
It was really sort of fantastic, all the great physicists that were coming in and out all the time.
What did you work on there that summer?
Can you tell me?
Yeah, it really didn't have anything to do with what they were primarily interested in.
It was just a new way of formulating the theory of gravity.
So it takes care of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Why was the development of atomic power plants so slow at this time when compared to research on weapons?
Even after the war, the material I've read, a lot of the efforts were directed toward more bigger, better weapons and not towards power plants.
Were the engineering and technical aspects just that tremendous or untenable or...
Or why was it the emphasis on weapons rather than power?
I don't know because I'm really competent to answer that.
I suppose.
The considerable amount of this was funded by military funds, and this necessarily gave it a push in that direction.
They felt that was the more urgent problem.
We obviously haven't had an energy shortage in this country until recent years, and so that wasn't an urgent problem.
familiar with the Price Anderson Act, where they will fund, I think it's 75 to something less than all but $96 million if there's an accident at nuclear power plants.
The federal government will fund, you know, it's like insurance.
Do you think that had some effect then on increasing research in power plants and bringing more power plants online afterwards?
Well, I'm sure encouraged bringing more online.
Do you think that had anything to do with the increased number of cyclotrons and synchrotrons and other accelerators?
Do you think research for power reactors
had more to do with that than, say, research for weapons.
And having more accelerators built?
Yes.
I doubt if there's a tremendous connection there.
There isn't that much you can do with accelerators to elucidate what's happening with reactors.
I suppose you need to measure a lot of these cross-sections better.
I think the main reason all the accelerators were built at universities is just that there was a lot of new nuclear physics, and the physicists wanted to do them.
I remember they built one here.
They were originally going to build one in West Virginia or something like that.
And the guy in charge of the Atomic Energy Commission at the time was from Texas A&M.
Oh, really?
Yeah.
So that's how we got our cyclotron.
He redirected it down here.
They had the whole scene set up there.
I'm pretty sure it was either the University of Virginia or the University of West Virginia.
They had everything.
I actually had a site funded in the whole business.
And then they changed the line just because this guy was an Aggie, and they built the cyclotron here instead of there.
I was surprised to read that, too.
After reading parts of the reactor safety study by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the review of that by the Union of Concerned Scientists, I was surprised at the odds
of some types of reactor accidents occurring and the damage that would occur.
Do you think reactors are relatively safe as a physicist?
I think so.
I think so.
The problems are all really engineering ones of water pipes that spring leaks and, you know, just down-to-earth daily problems of that sort.
And there are just so many engineering problems of that sort.
So it's not really a scientific problem when you get down to it.
No.
What improvements do you think they could make as far as nuclear reactors?
Well, I don't know if there's really that much.
I think it's more a question of having well-trained operators and having them built well and being sure there are no defects in these materials when they go in.
It seems to me that's where they've gotten in trouble in all the cases where they have.
Okay.
The scope of the study was real narrow, only quantifying the
The risks from the reactor itself, nothing to do with mining, enrichment, transportation.
Are these problems just too large, or are the risks insignificant?
From those aspects, the mining aspects and enrichment, moving it from one place to the next, do you think that those present a risk
Probably more than the reactor itself, or very little risk at all.
Well, of course, anything a human does involves some risk.
I know that you see studies that have been made of the risk in getting a ton of coal to burn in your power plant.
Some people claim that more lives are lost doing this than
could possibly have in getting the same amount of energy from a nuclear reactor.
Now, the things you're speaking of here are really essentially the same things you have in transporting coal, aren't they?
Yeah, mining is just as dangerous.
Mining isn't a great occupation.
Okay.
And the final thing is, did the scientists who were in that room on the 2nd of December, did they bear any of the responsibility for the proliferation of nuclear weapons or accidents from reactors?
Well, some of them, of course, formed the Federation of Atomic Scientists.
I think that's been quite a political force and has been quite a lot through the years.
educating people, particularly the legislators, as to what should happen.
I suspect that's the main positive thing they've done, other than just individually giving talks and things like that.
It's hard.
So the main, uh, you feel that the main reason then for this type of, uh, for all the

main nuclear research, the only way you can have it is with federal funding and that most of the things that come about from it are things that the only reason for them is because of the direction that the research has got to go because of the funding that's involved to begin with.
In other words, you know, for
military purposes, is that the reason that we have a lot of nuclear weapons?
Because the funding in nuclear research came from the Department of Defense rather than from, let's say, the Department of Energy now.
Well, are we talking about just this narrow field or all of nuclear physics research?
All of nuclear physics research.
Well, I think this is just this very small part of that.
And although the Department of Defense funds some of it, I don't think they're the major source of funds anymore.
The Department of Energy has funded a great deal of it.
Other agencies of the government.
Well, thank you very much, Dr. Foss.
I enjoyed it.
